Companion Dogs |[http://www.ukcdogs.com/Web.nsf/Breeds/CompanionDog/Poodle01012014 Standard, miniature, and toy] |} The '''poodle''' is a group of formal [[dog breed]]s, the '''Standard Poodle''', '''Miniature Poodle''' and '''Toy Poodle'''. The origin of the breed is still discussed, with a prominent dispute over whether the poodle descends from [[Germany]] as a [[Dog type|type]] of [[water dog]], or from the French [[Barbet (dog)|Barbet]]. *{{cite web|title=Breed Information Centre Poodle (Standard)|url=http://www.thekennelclub.org.uk/services/public/breed/display.aspx?id=4097|website=KC.org.uk|publisher=[[The Kennel Club]]|accessdate=15 January 2018|quote="''The Poodle originates in Germany, where it was bred as a water retriever, used by duck hunters.''"}} *{{cite web|title=Poodle History & Training|url=http://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/poodle/detail/|website=AKC.org|publisher=[[American Kennel Club]]|accessdate=15 January 2018|quote="''Despite the Poodle’s association with France, the breed originated as a duck hunter in Germany''"}} *{{cite web|title=Poodle (breed of dog)|url=https://www.britannica.com/animal/poodle|website=Britannica.oom|publisher= [[Encyclopædia Britannica]], Inc.|accessdate=15 January 2018}} *{{cite web|title=Poodle|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/plants-and-animals/animals/dogs/poodle|website=[[Encyclopedia.com]]|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]], Inc.|accessdate=15 January 2018}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.fci.be/Nomenclature/Standards/172g09-en.pdf|title=Fédération Cynologique Internationale: Poodle Breed Standard|accessdate=5 August 2016}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.centrale-canine.fr/le-chien-de-race/caniche|title=La Centrale Canine: Poodle Breed Standard.|accessdate=15 January 2018}} Ranked second most intelligent dog breed just behind the [[Border Collie]],{{cite web|url=http://www.stanleycoren.com/e_intelligence.htm|title=THE INTELLIGENCE OF DOGS|publisher=Stanleycoren.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} the poodle is skillful in many [[dog sports]] and activities, including agility, obedience, tracking to herding, circus performers or [[assistance dog]]s. Poodles have taken top honors in many [[conformation show]]s, including "Best in Show" at the [[Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show]] in 1991 and 2002, and at the [[World Dog Show]] in 2007 and 2010. Toy Poodles won "Best in Show" at [[Crufts]] in 1966 and 1982. Standard Poodles achieved the award in 1955, 1985, 2002, and 2014. The 2002 winner came from Norway and was the first overseas exhibit to win the Crufts best in show award.[[#dogdigital|''Dogworld: Digital Crufts Edition'' (2010)]]: p. 87[[#dogdigital|''Dogworld: Digital Crufts Edition'' (2010)]]: p. 84{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1865753.stm |title=Norwegian poodle wins Crufts |author= |date=10 March 2002 |work=|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=28 December 2009}} == History == [[File:Wenceslas Hollar - A poodle, after Matham.jpg|thumb|right|A 17th-century engraving of a poodle]] The origin of the poodle is disputed. [[The Kennel Club]] of the [[United Kingdom]] states that the breed originates in Germany{{cite web|title=Breed Information Centre Poodle (Standard)|url=http://www.thekennelclub.org.uk/services/public/breed/display.aspx?id=4097|website=KC.org.uk|publisher=[[The Kennel Club]]|accessdate=15 January 2018|quote="''The Poodle originates in Germany, where it was bred as a water retriever, used by duck hunters.''"}}, and the [[American Kennel Club]] of the [[United States]] concurs, stating: "Despite the Poodle’s association with France, the breed originated as a duck hunter in Germany..."{{cite web|title=Poodle History & Training|url=http://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/poodle/detail/|website=AKC.org|publisher=[[American Kennel Club]]|accessdate=15 January 2018|quote="''Despite the Poodle’s association with France, the breed originated as a duck hunter in Germany''"}} The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' and the ''[[American Heritage Dictionary]]'' both trace the etymology of ''Poodle'' to the German ''Pudel'', which itself comes from ''Pudel[[hund]].'' The word ''Pudel'' in turn comes from [[Low German]] ''pud(d)eln'' meaning "[to] splash in water,"{{cite web|title=Poodle|url=https://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=poodle|website=[[American Heritage Dictionary]]|publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]|accessdate=3 April 2018|quote=''[German Pudel, short for Pudelhund : Low German pudeln, to splash about (from pudel, puddle) + German Hund, dog.]''}}{{cite web|title=Definition of ''poodle'' in English.|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/poodle|website=[[Oxford English Dictionary]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|accessdate=3 April 2018|quote=''Early 19th century: from German Pudel(hund), from Low German pud(d)eln ‘splash in water’ (the poodle being a water-dog).''}} cognate with the English word ''[[puddle]]''. However, the [[Fédération Cynologique Internationale]], the international ogranization of which both France and Germany's main kennel clubs are memebrs, claims the breed descends from the French [[Barbet (dog)|Barbet]]. [http://www.fci.be/Nomenclature/Standards/172g09-en.pdf], Fédération Cynologique Internationale: Poodle Breed Standard. Retrieved 5 August 2016 The progenitor of the breed might have also been crossed with the Hungarian [[Puli]].{{cite book |last= Cuvier |first=Georges |date=1827 |title=The Animal Kingdom Arranged in Conformity with Its Organization |location= London|publisher= [[William Clowes Ltd.|William Clowes and Sons]]|page= |isbn= 978-1108049580 |author-link=Georges Cuvier }}. When the breed was officially recognized by the FCI, in order to avoid any possible dispute between two founding members, Germany recognized the Poodle as a dog originating from [[France]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} The French name ''Caniche'' comes from the word ''cane'' (the female of the duck) since this type of breed was used as a water retriever mainly for duck hunting thanks to its swimming ability.{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/poodle/detail/|title=From American Kennel Club site|publisher=Akc.org|accessdate=9 August 2016}} Due to the breed's popularity in France, it was claimed to be a national breed.{{cite web|title=Breed Information Centre Poodle (Standard)|url=http://www.thekennelclub.org.uk/services/public/breed/display.aspx?id=4097|website=KC.org.uk|publisher=[[The Kennel Club]]|accessdate=15 January 2018}} The European mainland had known the poodle long before it was brought to England. Drawings by German artist [[Albrecht Dürer]] established the popular image of the breed in the 15th and 16th centuries. It was the principal pet dog of the late 18th century in Spain, as shown by the paintings of the Spanish artist [[Francisco Goya]]. France had toy poodles as pampered favorites during the reign of Louis XVI at about the same period.{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/breeds/poodle/history.cfm |title=American Kennel Club - Poodle History |publisher=Akc.org |date= |accessdate=18 January 2010}} The poodle has contributed to many other dog breeds, such as the [[Miniature Schnauzer]],{{cite web |url=http://www.akc.org/breeds/miniature_schnauzer/history.cfm |title=Miniature Schnauzer History |work=AKC.org |accessdate=22 August 2008}} [[Standard Schnauzer]],{{cite web |url=http://www.standardschnauzer.org/ss_history.htm |title=A Brief History of the Standard Schnauzer |work=standardschnauzer.org |accessdate=22 April 2016}} and dogs of the [[Bichon]] type{{cite web |url=http://bichon.org/history-of-the-bichon-frise/ |title=History of the Bichon Frise |website=Bichon Frise Club of America, Inc. |access-date=22 April 2016}} in order to either save those breeds from [[extinction]], reduce size, or by [[Animal fancy|dog fanciers]] to improve their appearance. [[File:The Poodle, 1600s painting of the traditional poodle.png|thumb|The Poodle, 1700s painting of the traditional poodle]] ==Size variants== The poodle has been bred in at least three sizes, including '''Standard''', '''Miniature''', and '''Toy'''. According to the [[American Kennel Club]], which recognized the breed in 1887,{{cite web|title=Poodle|url=http://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/poodle/|publisher=American Kennel Club|accessdate=7 February 2017}} the Standard Poodle is the oldest of the three varieties,{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/breeds/poodle/index.cfm|title=From American Kennel Club site|publisher=Akc.org|accessdate=11 December 2014}} and was later bred down to the miniature and toy sizes. The British [[The Kennel Club|Kennel Club]] also recognizes three sizes, stating that the miniature and toy are scaled down versions of the standard.{{cite web|title=Breed Information Centre Poodle (Standard)|url=http://www.thekennelclub.org.uk/services/public/breed/display.aspx?id=4097|website=KC.org.uk|publisher=[[The Kennel Club]]|accessdate=15 January 2018}} The [[Fédération Cynologique Internationale]] (FCI) recognizes four sizes of one breed: standard, medium, miniature, and toy. Poodles exist in many [[Coat (dog)|coat]] colours. Despite the Standard Poodle's claim to greater age than the other varieties, some evidence shows the smaller types developed only a short time after the breed assumed the general type by which it is recognized today. The smallest, or Toy variety, was developed in England in the 18th century. Hunting and working dogs were typically of the standard variety, though some reports suggest that smaller varieties such as the miniature may have been popular for [[truffle hunting]], as their feet were less likely to damage the delicate fungi.{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/poodle/detail/|publisher=[[American Kennel Club]]|title=Poodle - Detail|accessdate=9 August 2016}} Miniature and Toy varieties tend to be bred primarily for companionship. In the mid to late 19th century, the trade in dyeing and affixing their fur to unusual proportions began with the need to compliment the Victorian and Georgian sensibilities of these women,{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2004/02/why_are_poodle_haircuts_so_weird.html|title=The genesis of the poodle hairdo.|work=Slate Magazine|accessdate=11 December 2014}} to the point that their status as a dog of the middle and upper classes was quite solid by the time of the founding of the [[Kennel Club]] in the 1870s as they were one of the first dog breeds registered. ==Work and sport== Traditionally the '''Standard Poodle''', the largest of the breed, was a retriever or [[gun dog]], used in particular for duck hunting and sometimes upland bird hunting. The breed has been used for fowl hunting in US and Canada since the early 1990s, in and out of hunting tests. The modern Standard retains many of the traits prized by their original owners: a keen working intelligence that makes the dog easy to command, webbed feet that make it an agile swimmer (all of the poodle's ancestors and descendants had or share the love of water) athletic stamina, and a moisture-resistant, curly coat that acts like a wool jumper in damp conditions. Towards the second half of the nineteenth century their use in hunting declined in favour of their use in circuses and status symbols of the wealthy, so that by the 20th century they were only found as companions or circus dogs.{{cite web|url=http://www.poodlehistory.org/PCIRCUS1.HTM|title=Circus bygone|publisher=Poodlehistory.org|accessdate=11 December 2014}} However, in the past 20 years, some breeders in the United States and Canada have been selecting for dogs with drive for birds in order to revive the breed for hunting, with some success.{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/sports/ci_8307818|title=Poodles ready to hunt|publisher=Denverpost.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} The [[Canadian Kennel Club]] admitted the Standard Poodle for hunting trials in 1996 and the [[American Kennel Club]] in 1998, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.fleetfiretimbers.com/FFT/Articles/TheUltimateFooFooReturnsToItsHistoricRoots.htm|title=The Ultimate Foo-Foo Returns To Its Historic Roots|author=Chris Robinson|publisher=Fleetfiretimbers.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} As of May 2017, the end results of 25 years of breeding to reawaken the hunting instinct have been a success. It has resulted in dogs that are very eager to please their masters. It has resulted in a gun dog with extreme intelligence, a relentless drive to catch its quarry, and strong swimming skills that requires special training: their aptitude is second only to the British [[Border Collie]] and thus the hunting Standard Poodle requires the gunman to be quite specific as to what he wants and how he wants it done. Unlike other spaniels and retrievers, Standard Poodles will attempt to solve a problem independently and need to be told specifically what is wanted when tracking and retrieving a bird. Because they are highly intelligent, harsh or violent training methods do not work with this dog breed in the field-corrections must be timely, given with precision and the trainer must have a firm but kind hand; an overbearing owner training his dog to hunt will find his Standard poodle terrified of his master and the entire experience, and refusing to budge an inch towards the water or into the brush.http://uplandgundog.com/the-standard-hunting-poodle/ [[File:Bo_the_poodle_retrieving_a_duck.jpg|thumb|Poodle retrieving a duck]]Hunting poodles typically are dogs with lightning quick reflexes, sprinting hard on command after the downed bird and having a prodigious ability to remember where the bird fell and (though not as good as the [[English Pointer]]) a decent nose to sniff and track a bird hiding in tall grass{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=cOEoAWACavI|title=Woodie at Madison.mpg|work=YouTube|accessdate=11 December 2014}}[http://www.waow.com/story/21725061/2013/03/19/outdoors-with-lauren-hunting-poodle] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130919142139/http://www.waow.com/story/21725061/2013/03/19/outdoors-with-lauren-hunting-poodle |date=19 September 2013 }} Recently, '''Miniature Poodles''' have also begun to be added to the list of hunters in the field: in January 2002, the Canadian Kennel Club opened their Working Certificate program to poodles of all sizes and later in 2014 the American Kennel club opened their Hunt Test program to miniature poodles; in 2017 both the Standard and Miniature were declared eligible for American Kennel Club Spaniel Tests, a program designed for testing dogs with flushing capabilities.{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/events/hunting-tests/retriever-hunting-test/eligible-breeds/|title=Eligible Breeds: Retriever Hunting Tests|work=akc.org}}https://www.poodleclubofamerica.org/all-about-poodles/activities-for-you-your-poodle/field-events{{cite web|url=http://beapudel.blogspot.com/p/diminutive-hunting-poodles.html|title=Diminutive Hunting Poodles|publisher=}} Typically, a Miniature Poodle will be the smallest dog of all in the field as it weighs less than 25 lbs or about 10 kg: this is even less than a [[Boykin Spaniel]], the former smallest dog, which weighs closer to 35 lbs, or 16 kg. However, hunters in the USA and Canada have found them very useful for [[American woodcock|woodcock]], [[Chukar partridge|chukar]], [[mallard]]s, and smaller ducks like the [[green-winged teal]] and [[bufflehead]]: their tiny size is an asset in getting at corners and brush that comparatively more massive retrievers cannot reach or where bramble is too thick for cocker spaniels to access.{{cite web|url=http://www.bestinshowdaily.com/pcas-field-weekend-the-start-of-the-greatest-show-on-earth/|title=Best In Show Daily|website=www.bestinshowdaily.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jibandsuzicope.com/Hunting.html|title=Hunting|website=www.jibandsuzicope.com}} Poodles have been used as working dogs in the military since at least the 17th century. During WWII, Roland Kilbon of the New York Sun, reported that other countries had used dogs in their armies for many years. In his column he quoted Mrs. Milton S. (Arlene) Erlanger, owner of Pillicoc Kennels, a premier breeder of Poodles "The dog must play a game in this thing." Eventually, "With the blessing of the American Kennel Club, the Professional Handlers Association, obedience training clubs across the country, and Seeing Eye, Inc., a nationwide program known as Dogs for Defense, Inc. was initiated and became the official procurement agency for all war dogs used in the Army, Navy and Coast Guard."{{cite web|last=Carter Isaacson|first=Suzanne|title=Poodles in WWII|url=http://www.poodlehistory.org/PoodlesinWWII.HTM|publisher=Poodle History Project|accessdate=5 February 2013}} Dogs for Defense procured the dogs who were then trained by the Army. In 1942, the Poodle was one of 32 breeds officially classified as war dogs by the Army. ==In competition== Standard Poodles have been winning titles against the more widely used native breeds like the [[Chesapeake Bay Retriever]], [[Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever]], [[American Water Spaniel]] and [[Labrador Retriever]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dec.ny.gov/docs/administration_pdf/1008duckdogs.pdf|format=PDF|title=New York hunters discover some unusual gundog breeds |author1=Elaine Bloom|author2=Colleen Kimble|publisher=Dec.ny.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Thus far 13 Standard Poodles have won Master Hunt titles (12 in the United States, 1 in Canada) and several more have won senior and junior titles on both sides of the border. Currently only the [[United Kennel Club]] in the US recognizes the Standard Poodle as a Sporting dog, thus in spite of this subtype of poodle being ineligible for field competitions more and more are appearing in the field as waterfowl dogs and hunters of pheasant in tall grass, the latter especially in the [[Midwest]].{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/outdoors/35629444.html|title=That dog hunts? Yes, poodles can make good hunting dogs, too|publisher=Startribune.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} ==Description== [[File:Pudel Grossschwarz.jpg|thumb|Black Standard Poodle]] ===Appearance=== The poodle is an active, intelligent and elegant dog, squarely built, and well proportioned. To ensure the desirable squarely built appearance, the length of body measured from the breastbone to the point of the rump approximates the height from the highest point of the shoulders to the ground. The eyes should be very dark, oval in shape, and have an alert and intelligent expression. The ears should fold over close to the head, set at, or slightly below, eye level. The coat should be of naturally curly texture, dense throughout, although most AKC-registered show dogs have a lion-cut or other, similarly shaven look. The sizes of the official AKC-recognized Poodle breeds are determined by height, not by weight. Poodles are bred in a variety of sizes, distinguished by adult shoulder ([[withers]]) height. The exact height cutoffs among the varieties vary slightly from country to country. The [[Fédération Cynologique Internationale]] (FCI) recognizes four sizes of one breed: standard, medium, miniature, and toy.{{cite web |url=http://www.fci.be/nomenclatures_detail.asp?lang=en&file=group9#section2 |title=Fédération Cynologique Internationale Group 9, Section 2, Poodle |publisher=Fci.be |date= |accessdate=18 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314004548/http://www.fci.be/nomenclatures_detail.asp?lang=en&file=group9#section2 |archivedate=14 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Non-FCI kennel clubs generally recognize three sizes, standard, miniature, and toy, sometimes as sizes of the same breed and sometimes as separate breeds. Only the FCI describes a maximum size for Standard Poodles. France is the country responsible for the breed in the FCI, and in this country, the puppies of all sizes are listed together.{{cite web|url=http://poodle.braquedubourbonnais.info/puppy.htm |title=List of poodle puppies registered to the French Kennel Club |publisher=scc.asso.fr|date= |accessdate=18 February 2006}} The terms royal standard, teacup, and tiny teacup are marketing names, and are not recognized by any major kennel club. {| class="wikitable" style="width:75%" |+ ''Comparison of poodle sizes defined by major kennel clubs''[http://www.fci.be/nomenclatures.asp?lang=en&sel=0 Fédération Cynologique Internationale breed nomenclature] *[http://www.thekennelclub.org.uk/item/435 The Kennel Club Dog Groups] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080824100509/http://www.thekennelclub.org.uk/item/435 |date=24 August 2008 }} *[http://www.ankc.aust.com/breeds_by_group.html Australian National Kennel Council breeds by group] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021040050/http://www.ankc.aust.com/breeds_by_group.html |date=21 October 2007 }} *[http://www.nzkc.org.nz/dogselect.html New Zealand Kennel Club Groups] *[http://www.ckc.ca/en/Default.aspx?tabid=89 Canadian Kennel Club breeds and Groups] *[http://www.akc.org/breeds/complete_breed_list.cfm# American Kennel Club complete breed list] ! style="width:14%;"| Size ! style="width:12%;"| [[The Kennel Club|The Kennel Club (UK)]] ! style="width:12%;"| [[Australian National Kennel Council]] ! style="width:12%;"| [[New Zealand Kennel Club]] ! style="width:12%;"| [[Canadian Kennel Club]] ! style="width:12%;"| [[American Kennel Club]] ! style="width:12%;"| [[United Kennel Club]] ! style="width:14%;"|[[Fédération Cynologique Internationale]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | Standard, ''Grand'' | |over {{convert|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} | |{{convert|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} and over | |{{convert|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} and over | | over {{convert|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | over {{convert|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | over {{convert|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|45|-|60|cm|in|abbr=on}} |- style="vertical-align: top;" | Medium, ''Moyen'' | | not used | | not used | | not used | |not used | | not used | | not used | |{{convert|35|-|45|cm|in|abbr=on}} |- style="vertical-align: top;" | Miniature - Dwarf, ''Nain'' | | {{convert|28|-|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|28|-|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|28|-|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|10|-|15|in|cm|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|10|-|15|in|cm|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|10|-|15|in|cm|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|28|-|35|cm|in|abbr=on}} |- style="vertical-align: top;" | Toy | | under {{convert|28|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | under {{convert|28|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | under {{convert|28|cm|in|abbr=on}} | | under {{convert|10|in|cm|abbr=on}} | | under {{convert|10|in|cm|abbr=on}} | | under {{convert|10|in|cm|abbr=on}} | | {{convert|24|-|28|cm|in|abbr=on}} |} All the Fédération Cynologique Internationale Poodles are in Group 9 Companion and Toy, Section 2 Poodle. All [[the Kennel Club]] poodles are in the [[Utility Group]]. All three sizes of poodles for the [[Australian National Kennel Council]] and the [[New Zealand Kennel Club]] are in the [[Non-sporting Group]]. The [[Canadian Kennel Club]] and the American Kennel Club place standard and miniature sizes in the Non-sporting Group, and the toy size in the [[Toy Group]]. The United Kennel Club places the miniature and toy in the [[Companion Group]] and the standard poodle in the [[Gundog Group]]. === Coat === Unlike most dogs which have double [[coat (dog)|coats]], poodles have a single layer coat (no undercoat is present) composed of dense, curly [[fur]]{{cite web |url= http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=what-is-the-difference-be |title=What is the difference between hair and fur? |work= [[Scientific American]] |publisher=Sciam.com |date=20 February 2001 |accessdate=18 January 2010}} that [[Moult|sheds]] minimally.{{cite web |url= http://www.marvistavet.com/html/body_canine_lymphoma.html |title= Canine Lymphoma |quote=Most breeds have hairs in all different stages of the growth-shed cycle at the same time. A few breeds [incl. poodle] have all hairs in the same stage of growth-shed at the same time. |publisher=Marvistavet.com |accessdate=21 April 2011 }} They could be considered [[hypoallergenic]] (though not completely allergen free).[https://web.archive.org/web/20071012032750/http://entdocs.org/catallergy.htm ''Allergic to Dogs, Is Any Dog Safe?''] Allergy site from an MD. Poodles, airedales, and schnauzers are cited as dogs that only shed their skin every 21 days, and so may be less of a problem for allergic people.{{cite news |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B07E0D61E3DF936A35751C0A961958260&n=Top/News/Science/Topics/Animals |title= Nonallergenic Dog? Not Really |first= Denise |last= Grady |work=The New York Times |date=5 February 1997 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }} How hypoallergenic the dog is may vary with the individual dog and the individual person. The poodle does shed, but instead of the fur coming off the dog, it becomes tangled in the surrounding hair. This can lead to matting without proper care. Texture ranges from coarse and woolly to soft and wavy. Poodle show clips require many hours of brushing and care per week, about 10 hours/week for a Standard Poodle. Poodles are usually clipped down into lower-maintenance cuts as soon as their show careers are over. Pet clips are much less elaborate than show and require much less maintenance. A pet owner can anticipate grooming a poodle every six to eight weeks. ===Clips === Generally, the owners clip their dogs as they want; however, if they want their dogs in conformation shows, a show clip is a requirement. Many breed registries allow only certain clips for poodles shown in conformation. In American Kennel Club (AKC) shows, adults must be shown in the "Continental" or "English saddle" clips. Dogs under 12 months old may be shown with a "puppy clip". The AKC allows the "Sporting" clip in Stud Dog and Brood Bitch classes, as well.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} Some sources believe the show clips evolved from working clips, which originally provided warmth to major joints when the dogs were immersed in cold water. The rest of the body is shaved for less drag in the water. Others express skepticism at this theory, instead citing the French [[circus]] as the origin of the entertaining and unique clips.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} The second puppy clip is also called the Scandinavian clip or puppy clip. It was invented by Swedish and Norwegian show groomers in the 1970s. It is the most common one in all sizes for shows in Europe, and is allowed for adult poodles to be shown in the [[Fédération Cynologique Internationale|FCI]] countries. The face, throat, belly, feet and the base of the tail are shaved five to seven days before the show to get a nice, smooth appearance of the shaved areas. The hair on the head is left to form a "topknot", fixed in place using latex bands, because in most European countries, hair spray is banned. The rest of the dog is shaped with scissors.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} In the continental clip, the face, throat, feet and part of the tail are shaved. The upper half of the front legs is shaved, leaving "fluffy pompons" around the ankles. The hindquarters are shaved except for pompons on the lower leg (from the [[hock (zoology)|hock]] to the base of the foot) and optional round areas (sometimes called "rosettes") over the hips. The continental clip is the most popular show clip today.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} The English saddle clip is similar to the continental, except for the hindquarters, which are not shaved except for a small, curved area on each flank (just behind the body), the feet, and bands just below the stifle (knee) and above the hock, leaving four (4) pompons. This clip is now rarely seen in standard poodles.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} Pet clips can be as simple or as elaborate as owners wish. The hair under the tail should always be kept short to keep feces from matting in the dog's curls. Most owners also keep the feet and face clipped short to prevent dirt from matting between toes, tear stains on lighter-coated poodles and food from matting around the dog's muzzle. Beyond these sanitary requirements, desired clips depend on owners' preferences. Some owners maintain a longer clip in winter than summer. === Corded coat === In most cases, whether a poodle is in a pet or show clip, the hair is completely brushed out. Poodle hair can also be "corded" with rope-like mats similar to those of a [[Komondor]] or human [[dreadlocks]]. Though once as common as the curly poodle, corded poodles are now rare. [[Cording (Dog Grooming)|Corded coats]] are difficult to keep clean and take a long time to dry after washing. Any poodle with a normal coat can be corded when its adult coat is in. Corded poodles may be shown in all major kennel club shows.{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/breeds/poodle/index.cfm |title=American Kennel Club: Poodle Breed Standard. Retrieved May 12, 2007 |publisher=Akc.org |date= |accessdate=18 January 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://mail.ukcdogs.com/UKCweb.nsf/80de88211ee3f2dc8525703f004ccb1e/77cc12b9230c0541852570490044c05a?OpenDocument|title=United Kennel Club: Standard Poodle Breed Standard. Retrieved May 12, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111073111/http://mail.ukcdogs.com/UKCweb.nsf/80de88211ee3f2dc8525703f004ccb1e/77cc12b9230c0541852570490044c05a?OpenDocument|archivedate=11 November 2006|df=dmy-all}} File:Corded Standard Poodle black.jpg|Corded Standard Poodle File:Toy Poodle in Riga 3.JPG|Toy Poodle Scandinavian clip File:Heidipuppy.jpg|11-month-old white Standard Poodle modern clip File:Poodle, cropped.JPG|White Standard Poodle Scandinavian clip, tail not [[Docking (dog)|docked]] File:Bullet 2010.jpg|Silver male Standard Poodle pet clip. File:Heidishow.jpg|White Standard Poodle Continental clip File:CH Renaissance Hopeful Impulse.jpg|Black Miniature Poodle Continental clip File:Jackie Vasteras 20070721-1.JPG|Poodle Scandinavian clip File:Standard poodle apricot.jpg|Cream Standard Poodle Lamb clip with high-shaved feet File:My dog back in Korea.png|Toy Poodle == Colours == The Poodle has a wide variety of colouring, including white, black, brown, parti, silver, gray, silver beige, apricot, red, cream, sable, and patterns such as phantom and [[brindle]]. The AKC recognizes Poodles in either solid-coloured or particoloured coats.{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/breeds/poodle/ |title=American Kennel Club - Poodle |publisher=Akc.org |date= |accessdate=23 August 2012}} Recognition of particolour (spotted) Poodles varies by registry. Phantom, brindle, and sable are considered out of standard by all major registries. Recognized FCI colourations are black, white, brown, gray, apricot, and red. For solid-coloured poodles, the coat is an even and solid colour at the skin. In blues, grays, silvers, browns, ''cafe-au-laits'', apricots and creams, the coat may show varying shades of the same colour. This is frequently present in the somewhat darker feathering of the ears and in the tipping of the ruff. While clear colours are preferred by registries, such natural variation in the shading of the coat is not to be considered a fault. Brown and ''cafe-au-lait'' poodles have liver-coloured noses, eye rims and lips, dark toenails and dark amber eyes. Black, blue, gray, silver, cream and white poodles have black noses, eye rims and lips, black or self-coloured toenails and very dark eyes. In the apricots, while the foregoing colouring is preferred, liver-coloured noses, eye rims and lips, and amber eyes are permitted, but are not desirable. Incomplete colour of nose, lips and eye rims, or a "mismatched" colour are considered faults by registries. Parti-coloured poodles are recognized in poodle history as the original colouring of the poodle.{{cite web|url=http://www.poodlehistory.org |title=Poodle History Project |publisher=Poodlehistory.org |date= |accessdate=23 August 2012}} A parti poodle has solid-coloured patches over a white coat. The coat will usually be white and coloured in equal amounts, though it can vary with a larger percent of white. Registries prefer that parti poodles have the same points as its correlating solid-coloured descendants. Brown and white parti poodles have liver-coloured noses, eye rims and lips, dark or self-coloured toenails and amber eyes. This is also permitted, but not preferred, in apricot and white parti poodles. Black/white, Blue/white, and silver/white poodles have black noses, eye rims and lips, black or self-coloured toenails and very dark eyes. When the dog has markings that resemble those of a [[tuxedo]], it is called a "tuxedo" poodle. The upper coat is solid: head, back, tail; and the lower coat is white: neck, chest, abdomen, and legs, making up usually 40% or more of the coat. Phantom poodles have the colouring of a [[Doberman Pinscher]], with a lighter colour appearing on their "eyebrows", muzzle and throat, legs and feet and below their tail. Like Dobermans, phantom poodles have either a black or brown main coat with a tan (usually apricot or red) lighter colourings around the eyebrows, muzzle, throat, legs, feet, and below their tail. File:Pudel kleinweiss.jpg|White Poodles File:Pudel Klein apricotred.jpg|Apricot and red Poodles File:Freddie (8467901543).jpg|Black Poodle Image:Blond Older Poodle Enjoying Water.JPG|Toy Poodle aged 16 still has an active life File:Maisiepuppydog.jpg|Brown Standard Poodle at five weeks File:Pudel Zwerg SilberShow.jpg|Mature grey Poodle File:Pudel Zwerg Blackandtan.jpg|Phantom Poodles File:Pudel ZwergHarlekin.jpg|Miniature Harlequin Poodle File:Gradowiki.jpg|Standard Poodle catching a ball File:No Fight - JM Staniforth.png|1898 political cartoon: Great Britain as the [[English Bulldog]]; France as the French Poodle == Temperament == Poodles are known as a highly intelligent, energetic, and sociable breed. They require both physical and intellectual activities. Of note is this breed's keen sense for instinctive behavior. In particular, [[territorial marking|marking]] and hunting drives are more readily observable in poodles than in most other breeds.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} A typical poodle should be reserved with strangers upon first introduction, but after a while should slowly reveal a warm and personable disposition. Snappy, vicious behavior is considered a serious fault in the breed.{{cite web|url=http://www.pethealth101.com/breeds/toy_poodle.shtml|title=Toy Poodles, Breeds from Pet Health 101|publisher=Pethealth101.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Poodles are highly trainable dogs that typically excel in obedience training. A poodle will do well at many dog sports, including [[dog agility]],{{cite web|url=http://www.vipoodle.org/AGP/VIP_agility.html|title=Versatility In Poodles - Agility Poodles|publisher=Vipoodle.org|accessdate=11 December 2014}} [[flyball]],{{cite web|url=http://www.flyball.org/cover_dogs_2013.html|title=North American Flyball Association - 2013 In the Spotlight|publisher=Flyball.org|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://flyball.com/fastfourward/team/Laredo.html|title=Laredo - Fast Fourward Flyball Team - San Diego, CA|publisher=Flyball.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} [[dock diving]],{{cite web|url=http://debbiewachel-artist.blogspot.com/2010/10/why-do-we-dock-dive.html|title=Insanity is a Terrible Thing to Waste: Why do we Dock Dive?|author=Debbie|publisher=Debbiewachel-artist.blogspot.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} field [[tracking trial|tracking]], and even [[schutzhund]],{{cite web|url=http://www.wasatchhundesport.com/?page_id=610|title=Frequently Asked Questions|work=Wasatch Hundesport|accessdate=11 December 2014}} and can follow owners on hiking trips or any trip involving swimming,{{cite web|url=http://www.petmd.com/dog/breeds/c_dg_poodle|title=Poodle Dogs- Poodle Dog Breed Info & Pictures - petMD|publisher=Petmd.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} as long as the dog is accustomed to water and swimming. Of the size varieties, Standard Poodles are the most highly recommended for families with children. They have a kindly demeanor and a love of playing games. As with all dogs and babies, introductions should be gradual, though most Standards will tolerate a baby and learn to be gentle and will respect toddlers so long as the child is supervized.{{cite web|url=http://www.poodlesavvy.com/poodle-dogs.html|title=Poodle Dogs and Children - Poodle Savvy|work=Poodle Savvy|accessdate=11 December 2014}} A Standard Poodle will be fine in a family with many children provided the environment is stable, orderly, and relaxed, with enough room for the dog to go out and retire to if needed.{{cite web|url=http://www.animalplanet.com/breed-selector/dog-breeds/non-sporting/poodle-standard.html|title=Poodle (Standard) : Dog Breed Selector : Animal Planet|work=Animal Planet|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.petwave.com/Dogs/Breeds/Poodle/Personality.aspx|title=Standard Poodle - Temperament & Personality|publisher=Petwave.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Miniature and Toy varieties tend to have less patience with young children and might find certain children's antics too much to handle, especially because young children are much larger than they are and may attempt to grab them without understanding how their attempt to hug the pooch is terrifying to a small dog. They are likely to bite out of fear and thus are better suited to homes with teenagers or older children.{{cite web|url=http://www.dogster.com/dog-breeds/Miniature_Poodle|title=Miniature Poodle Information, Pictures of Miniature Poodles - Dogster|publisher=Dogster.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Poodles dislike being left alone or left out of the family fun and some get anxious at being left in the house alone, but sign of nervousness or neurosis is atypical and not how a poodle of any size is meant to behave. == Health == The most common serious health issues of Standard Poodles listed in order of the number of reported cases in the [http://www.poodlehealthregistry.org/ Poodle Health Registry] (20 August 2007) are [[Addison's disease]], [[gastric dilatation volvulus]], [[thyroid]] issues (hyperthyroid and hypothyroid), [[tracheal collapse]], epilepsy, sebaceous [[adenitis]], juvenile renal disease, [[hip dysplasia (canine)|hip dysplasia]], and cancer. Standard Poodles are also susceptible to some health issues usually too minor to report to the health registry. The most common of these minor issues is probably ear infection. Ear infections are a problem in all poodle varieties because their nonshedding coat grows into the ear canal, where it traps wax and dirt. Ear problems can be minimized by proper ear care, including regular cleaning and plucking of hair within the ear canal. A [[veterinarian]] should be consulted if the dog shows signs of an ear infection. Standard Poodles in UK, Denmark and USA/Canada surveys had a median lifespan of 11.5 to 12 years.[http://users.pullman.com/lostriver/breeddata.htm Pullman.com] Dog Longevity Web Site. Compiled by K. M. Cassidy. Retrieved 28 June 2007. In a UK survey, the most common causes of death were cancer (30%), old age (18%), GDV (6%), and cardiac disease (5%).[http://www.thekennelclub.org.uk/item/570 Thekennelclub.org.uk], Kennel Club/British Small Animal Veterinary Association Scientific Committee. 2004. Purebred Dog Health Survey. Retrieved 28 June 2007. Miniature and Toy Poodles in UK surveys had median lifespans of 14 to 14.5 years. In Miniatures, the leading cause of death was old age (39%). In Toys, the leading causes of death were old age (25%), and kidney failure (20%). === Addison's disease === [[Addison's disease]] is (as of 20 August 2007) the illness most commonly reported to the Poodle Health Registry. The number of reported cases is nearly twice as high as the next most common problem (GDV). Addison's disease is characterized by insufficient production of glucocorticoid and/or mineralocortoid in the adrenal cortex (near the kidneys). Addison's is often undiagnosed because early symptoms are vague and easily mistaken for other conditions. Standard Poodles with unexplained lethargy, frequent gastric disturbances, or an inability to tolerate stress should be tested for it. Addison's can cause fatal sodium/potassium imbalances, but if caught early and treated with lifelong medication, most dogs can live a relatively normal life.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} === Gastric dilatation volvulus === There is a high incidence of [[gastric dilatation volvulus]] (GDV) in this breed, which occurs when twisting of the stomach (volvulus or torsion) causes or is caused by excess gas. Symptoms include restlessness, inability to get comfortable, pacing, or retching without being able to bring up anything. The dog's abdomen may be visibly swollen, but bloat or torsion can occur without visible swelling. A dog with GDV requires immediate veterinary care. The dog's survival usually depends on whether the owner can get to a veterinarian in time.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} GDV risk is increased with faster eating and a raised feeding bowl.{{cite web|url=http://www.2ndchance.info/bloat-Glickman2000.pdf|title=Non-dietary risk factors for gastric dilatation-volvulus in large and giant breed dogs|accessdate=16 December 2012}} === Reproduction === {| class="wikitable sortable; wikitable floatright" style="text-align:center" |+ Litter size at birth, stillborn, early neonatal mortality for poodles in the Norwegian Kennel Club{{Cite journal | last1 = Borge | first1 = K. S. | last3 = Nødtvedt | first3 = A. | last4 = Indrebø | first4 = A. | title = Canine perinatal mortality: A cohort study of 224 breeds | doi = 10.1016/j.theriogenology.2011.12.023 | journal = Theriogenology | volume = 77 | issue = 9 | pages = 1788–1801 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22365700| pmc = }} |- ! Toy Poodles have one of the smallest litter size of all breeds. The stillborn rate and early neonatal mortality (death within 1 week from birth) in poodles are lower than the average across all breeds. == Poodle crossbreeds == {{Main article|Poodle hybrid}} [[File:12-wk-cockpoo.JPG|thumb|right|Twelve-week-old [[Cockapoo]] puppy]] Poodles are crossed with other breeds for various reasons, and the resulting puppies (called [[designer dog]]s) are described by whimsical [[portmanteau word|''portmanteau'' words]], such as [[cockapoo]] or spoodle ([[Cocker Spaniel]]), maltipoo ([[Maltese (dog)|Maltese]]), [[goldendoodle]], [[labradoodle]] ([[Labrador Retriever|Labrador]]), [[Schnoodle]] ([[Schnauzer]]), [[Pekapoos]] ([[Pekingese]]), Cavapoo ([[Cavalier King Charles]]), [[Bernedoodle]] ([[Bernese Mountain Dog]]) and many others. A cross between a shedding breed and a poodle (which does not shed much) does not reliably produce a nonshedding dog. Traits of puppies from crossbreedings are not as predictable as those from purebred poodle breedings, and the crosses may shed or have unexpected or undesirable qualities from the parent breeds. Poodle crossbreds (also called hybrids) are not recognized by any major breed registry, as crossbreds are not one breed of dog, but two. If both parents are registered purebreds but of different breeds, it is still not possible to register a puppy as two different breeds. Some minor registries and Internet registry businesses will register dogs as any breed the owner chooses with minimal or no documentation; some even allow the breeder or owner to make up a new "breed name". == Hypoallergenic qualities == Poodles are often cited as a [[hypoallergenic dog breed]]. Their individual hair follicles have an active growth period that is longer than that of many other breeds of dogs; combined with the tightly curled [[coat (dog)|coat]], which slows the loss of [[dander]] and dead hair by trapping it in the curls, an individual poodle may release less dander and hair into the environment. In addition, most poodles are frequently brushed and bathed to keep them looking their best; this not only removes hair and dander, but also controls the other potent allergen, saliva.{{cite web|url=http://www.dogplay.com/Articles/MyArticles/hair_vs_fur.html |title=Hair vs Fur |publisher=Dogplay.com |date= |accessdate=18 January 2010}} Although hair, dander, and saliva can be minimized, they are still present and can stick to "clothes and the carpets and furnishings in your home"; inhaling them, or being licked by the dog, can trigger a reaction in a sensitive person. An air cleaner, air duct outlet and vacuuming with a vacuum cleaner with a [[HEPA]] filter can help clear dander floating in the air.[http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/pet-allergy/DS00859/DSECTION=lifestyle-and-home-remedies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081215141920/http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/pet-allergy/DS00859/DSECTION=lifestyle-and-home-remedies |date=15 December 2008 }} The word hypoallergenic, when referring to a dog, is also a misconception; all dogs shed. Poodles shed hair in minimal amounts, and also release dander, but are not as likely to trigger allergies as much as many other breeds. Additionally, poodle maintenance must include some amount of regular shaving, which releases hair dust in the air. == Cultural visibility == {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2018}} Poodles are commonly known as extensively groomed show dogs and companions with a distinctive clip, to such a degree that poodles in short pet clips often go unrecognized or mistaken as Poodle crosses ("Doodles"). This association of the breed's appearance and the resulting preconceptions is strong, and reflects in popular culture, where poodles most often are depicted as spoiled and perhaps obnoxious pets, or if anthropomorphic, snobby, selfish, and vain. Poodle owners are perceived stereotypically as fussy, frivolous, and impractical. == Notes == {{refbegin}} '''Note 1.''' {{Note_label|1|note 1|none}} Fur is defined by the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' as "the short, soft hair of certain animals"{{cite web|author=Askoxford.com |url=http://www.askoxford.com/80/concise_oed/fur?view=uk |title=Oxford Dictionaries, Ask Oxford - fur |publisher=Askoxford.com |date= |accessdate=18 January 2010}} whereas hair is defined as "any of the fine thread-like strands growing from the skin of mammals and other animals, or from the epidermis of a plant."{{cite web|author=Askoxford.com |url=http://www.askoxford.com/concise_oed/hair?view=uk |title=Oxford Dictionaries, Ask Oxford - hair |publisher=Askoxford.com |date= |accessdate=18 January 2010}} {{refend}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Animals|Dogs|France|Germany}} {{commons|Poodle}} * {{dmoz|Recreation/Pets/Dogs/Breeds/NonSporting-Utility_Group/Poodle/}} {{French dogs}} {{German dogs}} {{Gundogs}} {{Toy dogs}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Dog breeds originating in France]] [[Category:Dog breeds originating in Germany]] [[Category:Companion dogs]] [[Category:Dog breeds]]

The poodle is a group of formal dog breeds, the Standard Poodle, Miniature Poodle and Toy Poodle. The origin of the breed is still discussed, with a prominent dispute over whether the poodle descends from Germany as a type of water dog, or from the French Barbet.[5]

Ranked second most intelligent dog breed just behind the Border Collie,[6] the poodle is skillful in many dog sports and activities, including agility, obedience, tracking to herding, circus performers or assistance dogs. Poodles have taken top honors in many conformation shows, including "Best in Show" at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in 1991 and 2002, and at the World Dog Show in 2007 and 2010.

Toy Poodles won "Best in Show" at Crufts in 1966 and 1982. Standard Poodles achieved the award in 1955, 1985, 2002, and 2014. The 2002 winner came from Norway and was the first overseas exhibit to win the Crufts best in show award.[7][8][9]

History

A 17th-century engraving of a poodle

The origin of the poodle is disputed. The Kennel Club of the United Kingdom states that the breed originates in Germany[10], and the American Kennel Club of the United States concurs, stating: "Despite the Poodle’s association with France, the breed originated as a duck hunter in Germany..."[11] The Oxford English Dictionary and the American Heritage Dictionary both trace the etymology of Poodle to the German Pudel, which itself comes from Pudelhund. The word Pudel in turn comes from Low German pud(d)eln meaning "[to] splash in water,"[12][13] cognate with the English word puddle.

However, the Fédération Cynologique Internationale, the international ogranization of which both France and Germany's main kennel clubs are memebrs, claims the breed descends from the French Barbet. [3] The progenitor of the breed might have also been crossed with the Hungarian Puli.[14]. When the breed was officially recognized by the FCI, in order to avoid any possible dispute between two founding members, Germany recognized the Poodle as a dog originating from France.[citation needed] The French name Caniche comes from the word cane (the female of the duck) since this type of breed was used as a water retriever mainly for duck hunting thanks to its swimming ability.[15] Due to the breed's popularity in France, it was claimed to be a national breed.[16]

The European mainland had known the poodle long before it was brought to England. Drawings by German artist Albrecht Dürer established the popular image of the breed in the 15th and 16th centuries. It was the principal pet dog of the late 18th century in Spain, as shown by the paintings of the Spanish artist Francisco Goya. France had toy poodles as pampered favorites during the reign of Louis XVI at about the same period.[17]

The poodle has contributed to many other dog breeds, such as the Miniature Schnauzer,[18] Standard Schnauzer,[19] and dogs of the Bichon type[20] in order to either save those breeds from extinction, reduce size, or by dog fanciers to improve their appearance.

The Poodle, 1700s painting of the traditional poodle

Size variants

The poodle has been bred in at least three sizes, including Standard, Miniature, and Toy. According to the American Kennel Club, which recognized the breed in 1887,[21] the Standard Poodle is the oldest of the three varieties,[22] and was later bred down to the miniature and toy sizes. The British Kennel Club also recognizes three sizes, stating that the miniature and toy are scaled down versions of the standard.[23] The Fédération Cynologique Internationale (FCI) recognizes four sizes of one breed: standard, medium, miniature, and toy. Poodles exist in many coat colours. Despite the Standard Poodle's claim to greater age than the other varieties, some evidence shows the smaller types developed only a short time after the breed assumed the general type by which it is recognized today.

The smallest, or Toy variety, was developed in England in the 18th century. Hunting and working dogs were typically of the standard variety, though some reports suggest that smaller varieties such as the miniature may have been popular for truffle hunting, as their feet were less likely to damage the delicate fungi.[24] Miniature and Toy varieties tend to be bred primarily for companionship. In the mid to late 19th century, the trade in dyeing and affixing their fur to unusual proportions began with the need to compliment the Victorian and Georgian sensibilities of these women,[25] to the point that their status as a dog of the middle and upper classes was quite solid by the time of the founding of the Kennel Club in the 1870s as they were one of the first dog breeds registered.

Work and sport

Traditionally the Standard Poodle, the largest of the breed, was a retriever or gun dog, used in particular for duck hunting and sometimes upland bird hunting. The breed has been used for fowl hunting in US and Canada since the early 1990s, in and out of hunting tests. The modern Standard retains many of the traits prized by their original owners: a keen working intelligence that makes the dog easy to command, webbed feet that make it an agile swimmer (all of the poodle's ancestors and descendants had or share the love of water) athletic stamina, and a moisture-resistant, curly coat that acts like a wool jumper in damp conditions. Towards the second half of the nineteenth century their use in hunting declined in favour of their use in circuses and status symbols of the wealthy, so that by the 20th century they were only found as companions or circus dogs.[26] However, in the past 20 years, some breeders in the United States and Canada have been selecting for dogs with drive for birds in order to revive the breed for hunting, with some success.[27] The Canadian Kennel Club admitted the Standard Poodle for hunting trials in 1996 and the American Kennel Club in 1998, respectively.[28]

As of May 2017, the end results of 25 years of breeding to reawaken the hunting instinct have been a success. It has resulted in dogs that are very eager to please their masters. It has resulted in a gun dog with extreme intelligence, a relentless drive to catch its quarry, and strong swimming skills that requires special training: their aptitude is second only to the British Border Collie[6] and thus the hunting Standard Poodle requires the gunman to be quite specific as to what he wants and how he wants it done. Unlike other spaniels and retrievers, Standard Poodles will attempt to solve a problem independently and need to be told specifically what is wanted when tracking and retrieving a bird. Because they are highly intelligent, harsh or violent training methods do not work with this dog breed in the field-corrections must be timely, given with precision and the trainer must have a firm but kind hand; an overbearing owner training his dog to hunt will find his Standard poodle terrified of his master and the entire experience, and refusing to budge an inch towards the water or into the brush.[29]

Poodle retrieving a duck

Hunting poodles typically are dogs with lightning quick reflexes, sprinting hard on command after the downed bird and having a prodigious ability to remember where the bird fell and (though not as good as the English Pointer) a decent nose to sniff and track a bird hiding in tall grass[30][31] Recently, Miniature Poodles have also begun to be added to the list of hunters in the field: in January 2002, the Canadian Kennel Club opened their Working Certificate program to poodles of all sizes and later in 2014 the American Kennel club opened their Hunt Test program to miniature poodles; in 2017 both the Standard and Miniature were declared eligible for American Kennel Club Spaniel Tests, a program designed for testing dogs with flushing capabilities.[32][33][34] Typically, a Miniature Poodle will be the smallest dog of all in the field as it weighs less than 25 lbs or about 10 kg: this is even less than a Boykin Spaniel, the former smallest dog, which weighs closer to 35 lbs, or 16 kg. However, hunters in the USA and Canada have found them very useful for woodcock, chukar, mallards, and smaller ducks like the green-winged teal and bufflehead: their tiny size is an asset in getting at corners and brush that comparatively more massive retrievers cannot reach or where bramble is too thick for cocker spaniels to access.[35][36]

Poodles have been used as working dogs in the military since at least the 17th century. During WWII, Roland Kilbon of the New York Sun, reported that other countries had used dogs in their armies for many years. In his column he quoted Mrs. Milton S. (Arlene) Erlanger, owner of Pillicoc Kennels, a premier breeder of Poodles "The dog must play a game in this thing." Eventually, "With the blessing of the American Kennel Club, the Professional Handlers Association, obedience training clubs across the country, and Seeing Eye, Inc., a nationwide program known as Dogs for Defense, Inc. was initiated and became the official procurement agency for all war dogs used in the Army, Navy and Coast Guard."[37] Dogs for Defense procured the dogs who were then trained by the Army. In 1942, the Poodle was one of 32 breeds officially classified as war dogs by the Army.

In competition

Standard Poodles have been winning titles against the more widely used native breeds like the Chesapeake Bay Retriever, Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever, American Water Spaniel and Labrador Retriever.[38] Thus far 13 Standard Poodles have won Master Hunt titles (12 in the United States, 1 in Canada) and several more have won senior and junior titles on both sides of the border. Currently only the United Kennel Club in the US recognizes the Standard Poodle as a Sporting dog, thus in spite of this subtype of poodle being ineligible for field competitions more and more are appearing in the field as waterfowl dogs and hunters of pheasant in tall grass, the latter especially in the Midwest.[39]

Description

Black Standard Poodle

Appearance

The poodle is an active, intelligent and elegant dog, squarely built, and well proportioned. To ensure the desirable squarely built appearance, the length of body measured from the breastbone to the point of the rump approximates the height from the highest point of the shoulders to the ground. The eyes should be very dark, oval in shape, and have an alert and intelligent expression. The ears should fold over close to the head, set at, or slightly below, eye level. The coat should be of naturally curly texture, dense throughout, although most AKC-registered show dogs have a lion-cut or other, similarly shaven look. The sizes of the official AKC-recognized Poodle breeds are determined by height, not by weight.

Poodles are bred in a variety of sizes, distinguished by adult shoulder (withers) height. The exact height cutoffs among the varieties vary slightly from country to country. The Fédération Cynologique Internationale (FCI) recognizes four sizes of one breed: standard, medium, miniature, and toy.[40] Non-FCI kennel clubs generally recognize three sizes, standard, miniature, and toy, sometimes as sizes of the same breed and sometimes as separate breeds. Only the FCI describes a maximum size for Standard Poodles. France is the country responsible for the breed in the FCI, and in this country, the puppies of all sizes are listed together.[41] The terms royal standard, teacup, and tiny teacup are marketing names, and are not recognized by any major kennel club.

Coat

Unlike most dogs which have double coats, poodles have a single layer coat (no undercoat is present) composed of dense, curly fur[43] that sheds minimally.[44] They could be considered hypoallergenic (though not completely allergen free).[45][46] The poodle does shed, but instead of the fur coming off the dog, it becomes tangled in the surrounding hair. This can lead to matting without proper care. Texture ranges from coarse and woolly to soft and wavy. Poodle show clips require many hours of brushing and care per week, about 10 hours/week for a Standard Poodle. Poodles are usually clipped down into lower-maintenance cuts as soon as their show careers are over. Pet clips are much less elaborate than show and require much less maintenance. A pet owner can anticipate grooming a poodle every six to eight weeks.

Clips

Generally, the owners clip their dogs as they want; however, if they want their dogs in conformation shows, a show clip is a requirement. Many breed registries allow only certain clips for poodles shown in conformation. In American Kennel Club (AKC) shows, adults must be shown in the "Continental" or "English saddle" clips. Dogs under 12 months old may be shown with a "puppy clip". The AKC allows the "Sporting" clip in Stud Dog and Brood Bitch classes, as well.[citation needed]

Some sources believe the show clips evolved from working clips, which originally provided warmth to major joints when the dogs were immersed in cold water. The rest of the body is shaved for less drag in the water. Others express skepticism at this theory, instead citing the French circus as the origin of the entertaining and unique clips.[citation needed]

The second puppy clip is also called the Scandinavian clip or puppy clip. It was invented by Swedish and Norwegian show groomers in the 1970s. It is the most common one in all sizes for shows in Europe, and is allowed for adult poodles to be shown in the FCI countries. The face, throat, belly, feet and the base of the tail are shaved five to seven days before the show to get a nice, smooth appearance of the shaved areas. The hair on the head is left to form a "topknot", fixed in place using latex bands, because in most European countries, hair spray is banned. The rest of the dog is shaped with scissors.[citation needed]

In the continental clip, the face, throat, feet and part of the tail are shaved. The upper half of the front legs is shaved, leaving "fluffy pompons" around the ankles. The hindquarters are shaved except for pompons on the lower leg (from the hock to the base of the foot) and optional round areas (sometimes called "rosettes") over the hips. The continental clip is the most popular show clip today.[citation needed]

The English saddle clip is similar to the continental, except for the hindquarters, which are not shaved except for a small, curved area on each flank (just behind the body), the feet, and bands just below the stifle (knee) and above the hock, leaving four (4) pompons. This clip is now rarely seen in standard poodles.[citation needed]

Pet clips can be as simple or as elaborate as owners wish. The hair under the tail should always be kept short to keep feces from matting in the dog's curls. Most owners also keep the feet and face clipped short to prevent dirt from matting between toes, tear stains on lighter-coated poodles and food from matting around the dog's muzzle. Beyond these sanitary requirements, desired clips depend on owners' preferences. Some owners maintain a longer clip in winter than summer.

Corded coat

In most cases, whether a poodle is in a pet or show clip, the hair is completely brushed out. Poodle hair can also be "corded" with rope-like mats similar to those of a Komondor or human dreadlocks. Though once as common as the curly poodle, corded poodles are now rare. Corded coats are difficult to keep clean and take a long time to dry after washing. Any poodle with a normal coat can be corded when its adult coat is in. Corded poodles may be shown in all major kennel club shows.[3][47][48]

Colours

The Poodle has a wide variety of colouring, including white, black, brown, parti, silver, gray, silver beige, apricot, red, cream, sable, and patterns such as phantom and brindle. The AKC recognizes Poodles in either solid-coloured or particoloured coats.[49] Recognition of particolour (spotted) Poodles varies by registry. Phantom, brindle, and sable are considered out of standard by all major registries. Recognized FCI colourations are black, white, brown, gray, apricot, and red.

For solid-coloured poodles, the coat is an even and solid colour at the skin. In blues, grays, silvers, browns, cafe-au-laits, apricots and creams, the coat may show varying shades of the same colour. This is frequently present in the somewhat darker feathering of the ears and in the tipping of the ruff. While clear colours are preferred by registries, such natural variation in the shading of the coat is not to be considered a fault. Brown and cafe-au-lait poodles have liver-coloured noses, eye rims and lips, dark toenails and dark amber eyes. Black, blue, gray, silver, cream and white poodles have black noses, eye rims and lips, black or self-coloured toenails and very dark eyes. In the apricots, while the foregoing colouring is preferred, liver-coloured noses, eye rims and lips, and amber eyes are permitted, but are not desirable. Incomplete colour of nose, lips and eye rims, or a "mismatched" colour are considered faults by registries.

Parti-coloured poodles are recognized in poodle history as the original colouring of the poodle.[50] A parti poodle has solid-coloured patches over a white coat. The coat will usually be white and coloured in equal amounts, though it can vary with a larger percent of white. Registries prefer that parti poodles have the same points as its correlating solid-coloured descendants. Brown and white parti poodles have liver-coloured noses, eye rims and lips, dark or self-coloured toenails and amber eyes. This is also permitted, but not preferred, in apricot and white parti poodles. Black/white, Blue/white, and silver/white poodles have black noses, eye rims and lips, black or self-coloured toenails and very dark eyes. When the dog has markings that resemble those of a tuxedo, it is called a "tuxedo" poodle. The upper coat is solid: head, back, tail; and the lower coat is white: neck, chest, abdomen, and legs, making up usually 40% or more of the coat.

Phantom poodles have the colouring of a Doberman Pinscher, with a lighter colour appearing on their "eyebrows", muzzle and throat, legs and feet and below their tail. Like Dobermans, phantom poodles have either a black or brown main coat with a tan (usually apricot or red) lighter colourings around the eyebrows, muzzle, throat, legs, feet, and below their tail.

Temperament

Poodles are known as a highly intelligent, energetic, and sociable breed. They require both physical and intellectual activities. Of note is this breed's keen sense for instinctive behavior. In particular, marking and hunting drives are more readily observable in poodles than in most other breeds.[citation needed] A typical poodle should be reserved with strangers upon first introduction, but after a while should slowly reveal a warm and personable disposition. Snappy, vicious behavior is considered a serious fault in the breed.[51]

Poodles are highly trainable dogs that typically excel in obedience training. A poodle will do well at many dog sports, including dog agility,[52] flyball,[53][54] dock diving,[55] field tracking, and even schutzhund,[56] and can follow owners on hiking trips or any trip involving swimming,[57] as long as the dog is accustomed to water and swimming.

Of the size varieties, Standard Poodles are the most highly recommended for families with children. They have a kindly demeanor and a love of playing games. As with all dogs and babies, introductions should be gradual, though most Standards will tolerate a baby and learn to be gentle and will respect toddlers so long as the child is supervized.[58] A Standard Poodle will be fine in a family with many children provided the environment is stable, orderly, and relaxed, with enough room for the dog to go out and retire to if needed.[59][60] Miniature and Toy varieties tend to have less patience with young children and might find certain children's antics too much to handle, especially because young children are much larger than they are and may attempt to grab them without understanding how their attempt to hug the pooch is terrifying to a small dog. They are likely to bite out of fear and thus are better suited to homes with teenagers or older children.[61] Poodles dislike being left alone or left out of the family fun and some get anxious at being left in the house alone, but sign of nervousness or neurosis is atypical and not how a poodle of any size is meant to behave.

Health

The most common serious health issues of Standard Poodles listed in order of the number of reported cases in the Poodle Health Registry (20 August 2007) are Addison's disease, gastric dilatation volvulus, thyroid issues (hyperthyroid and hypothyroid), tracheal collapse, epilepsy, sebaceous adenitis, juvenile renal disease, hip dysplasia, and cancer. Standard Poodles are also susceptible to some health issues usually too minor to report to the health registry. The most common of these minor issues is probably ear infection. Ear infections are a problem in all poodle varieties because their nonshedding coat grows into the ear canal, where it traps wax and dirt. Ear problems can be minimized by proper ear care, including regular cleaning and plucking of hair within the ear canal. A veterinarian should be consulted if the dog shows signs of an ear infection.

Standard Poodles in UK, Denmark and USA/Canada surveys had a median lifespan of 11.5 to 12 years.[62] In a UK survey, the most common causes of death were cancer (30%), old age (18%), GDV (6%), and cardiac disease (5%).[63]

Miniature and Toy Poodles in UK surveys had median lifespans of 14 to 14.5 years.[62] In Miniatures, the leading cause of death was old age (39%).[63] In Toys, the leading causes of death were old age (25%), and kidney failure (20%).[63]

Addison's disease

Addison's disease is (as of 20 August 2007) the illness most commonly reported to the Poodle Health Registry. The number of reported cases is nearly twice as high as the next most common problem (GDV). Addison's disease is characterized by insufficient production of glucocorticoid and/or mineralocortoid in the adrenal cortex (near the kidneys). Addison's is often undiagnosed because early symptoms are vague and easily mistaken for other conditions. Standard Poodles with unexplained lethargy, frequent gastric disturbances, or an inability to tolerate stress should be tested for it. Addison's can cause fatal sodium/potassium imbalances, but if caught early and treated with lifelong medication, most dogs can live a relatively normal life.[citation needed]

Gastric dilatation volvulus

There is a high incidence of gastric dilatation volvulus (GDV) in this breed, which occurs when twisting of the stomach (volvulus or torsion) causes or is caused by excess gas. Symptoms include restlessness, inability to get comfortable, pacing, or retching without being able to bring up anything. The dog's abdomen may be visibly swollen, but bloat or torsion can occur without visible swelling. A dog with GDV requires immediate veterinary care. The dog's survival usually depends on whether the owner can get to a veterinarian in time.[citation needed] GDV risk is increased with faster eating and a raised feeding bowl.[64]

Breed size is correlated with litter size and Standard Poodles have the highest litter size followed by Medium, Miniature, and Toy. Toy Poodles have one of the smallest litter size of all breeds.[65] The stillborn rate and early neonatal mortality (death within 1 week from birth) in poodles are lower than the average across all breeds.[66]

Poodle crossbreeds

Main article: Poodle hybrid
Twelve-week-old Cockapoo puppy

Poodles are crossed with other breeds for various reasons, and the resulting puppies (called designer dogs) are described by whimsical portmanteau words, such as cockapoo or spoodle (Cocker Spaniel), maltipoo (Maltese), goldendoodle, labradoodle (Labrador), Schnoodle (Schnauzer), Pekapoos (Pekingese), Cavapoo (Cavalier King Charles), Bernedoodle (Bernese Mountain Dog) and many others.

A cross between a shedding breed and a poodle (which does not shed much) does not reliably produce a nonshedding dog. Traits of puppies from crossbreedings are not as predictable as those from purebred poodle breedings, and the crosses may shed or have unexpected or undesirable qualities from the parent breeds.

Poodle crossbreds (also called hybrids) are not recognized by any major breed registry, as crossbreds are not one breed of dog, but two. If both parents are registered purebreds but of different breeds, it is still not possible to register a puppy as two different breeds. Some minor registries and Internet registry businesses will register dogs as any breed the owner chooses with minimal or no documentation; some even allow the breeder or owner to make up a new "breed name".

Hypoallergenic qualities

Poodles are often cited as a hypoallergenic dog breed. Their individual hair follicles have an active growth period that is longer than that of many other breeds of dogs; combined with the tightly curled coat, which slows the loss of dander and dead hair by trapping it in the curls, an individual poodle may release less dander and hair into the environment. In addition, most poodles are frequently brushed and bathed to keep them looking their best; this not only removes hair and dander, but also controls the other potent allergen, saliva.[67]

Although hair, dander, and saliva can be minimized, they are still present and can stick to "clothes and the carpets and furnishings in your home"; inhaling them, or being licked by the dog, can trigger a reaction in a sensitive person. An air cleaner, air duct outlet and vacuuming with a vacuum cleaner with a HEPA filter can help clear dander floating in the air.[68]

The word hypoallergenic, when referring to a dog, is also a misconception; all dogs shed. Poodles shed hair in minimal amounts, and also release dander, but are not as likely to trigger allergies as much as many other breeds. Additionally, poodle maintenance must include some amount of regular shaving, which releases hair dust in the air.

Cultural visibility
This section does not cite any sources. Please help improve this section by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (April 2018) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

Poodles are commonly known as extensively groomed show dogs and companions with a distinctive clip, to such a degree that poodles in short pet clips often go unrecognized or mistaken as Poodle crosses ("Doodles"). This association of the breed's appearance and the resulting preconceptions is strong, and reflects in popular culture, where poodles most often are depicted as spoiled and perhaps obnoxious pets, or if anthropomorphic, snobby, selfish, and vain. Poodle owners are perceived stereotypically as fussy, frivolous, and impractical.
